PARA.TAB: Regrettably, I have to report another dimension to that lack of credibility of the minister involving a recent case of medical treatment of one of my constituents. It is clear to my constituent that Dr Lawrence's untruthful behaviour revealed by Commissioner Marks is now matched by the ideologically driven attitude of her office and her department to the health problems of ordinary battlers.

Consistently, in debates in this place and in her public utterances, Dr Lawrence has set out to play down the merits of private health insurance, to beat up the infallibility of Medicare and the public health system, to put many doctors in a collective category as excessive chargers of their services or to bag the avaricious nature of the AMA. Dr Lawrence's office in particular has a persistence for politics over portfolio, and my constituent's problem proves the point.

Last week I was faced both with a practical example of some of the serious shortcomings of Dr Lawrence's present health system and with the political emphasis of Dr Lawrence's office and her department rather than with their genuine interest in the health care problems of a distraught local housewife threatening suicide. The lady involved, who was diagnosed with degenerative spondylosis over five years ago, has been forced to pay nearly $90,000 out of her own pocket in that time to meet hospital and medical bills, despite medical insurance. More expense is likely, possibly in the order of $15,000 of personal liability, as a result of further operations in the near future.

To meet these financial commitments, she and her average income police sergeant husband have been forced into bank loans and further financial stress. Personal family relationships are at a breaking point. The extent of their financial liability results from a combination of factors, such as the unrealistic schedule fees determined by the government under Medicare arrangements, the increasing gap between Medicare refunds and consultancy or service charges, the outpatient inadequacies of Medicare arrangements and the unfortunate tendency of some doctors to charge substantially above the schedule fee or AMA recommended level—although in this case I have to say that the specialist concerned is continuing to carry the lady's large debt.

However, it is the negative attitude of Dr Lawrence's office and her department to the specific problem that has caused deep despair to this couple, who came to see me only last week. When my electorate office phoned Dr Lawrence's Canberra office early last week seeking urgent advice in light of the lady's suicidal tendencies, her staff were just not interested. `If she is a private patient, we can't help,' was the general reaction, and they referred my office to the department.

Although the department conceded that it was one of the worst cases brought to their attention, the blame was shifted quickly to ideological criticisms of private health insurance and the lack of Commonwealth power over doctors' fees. In a nutshell, the simplistic, unhelpful attitude was: the lady would have been better off as a public patient where the problem would not have arisen. This is patently untrue, as Queensland public hospital queues will attest.

A very disturbing additional dimension to the problem was a suggestion that the couple might separate so that the lady could claim the invalid pension. So much for the government's infallible Medicare arrangements and its unequivocal social awareness. Clearly, there is a big difference between the Commonwealth paying the legal fees of Dr Lawrence and a genuine desire to assist this desperate lady—and many like her—under Medicare arrangements which remain inadequate.

My concern is for the lady's welfare, as indeed it is incumbent on Dr Lawrence to be just as concerned. The lady places much of the blame squarely at the feet of Dr Lawrence, who continues to demonstrate her unsuitability for ministerial responsibility. A letter to the editor in yesterday's Brisbane Courier-Mail put the Lawrence debacle in a nutshell when it said:

SPEECH.PARA: If Carmen Lawrence looks like a duck, walks like a duck, quacks like a duck and tried to duck the royal commission—

TALK.START.PARA: —Some 12 to 14 months ago, I, along with a number of my colleagues from Queensland, Western Australia and New South Wales, joined together to form the fair share task force to fight for an increase in tertiary places for Queensland. It is well known to this House that Queensland had not been getting its fair allocation of tertiary places and that universities in western Sydney and in Western Australia had also not been getting their fair share of places allocated by federal funds. So we formed the fair share task force and took our case to the federal Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Simon Crean.

PARA.TAB: The minister was very responsive to our case and understood that there was a need for a redress in the balance of distribution of places. He undertook to do what he could in the budget to try to find the extra funding for those tertiary places. We spent some months working with the minister to try to find ways in which we could find those additional tertiary places. It was a great joy to Queenslanders, particularly those Queensland families that have young people leaving year 12 this year, to find that in the budget the federal government was able to find measures to achieve additional funding so that Queensland could get an additional 4,200 extra places. What that extra allocation meant was that Queensland students were going to get their fair share and that young Queenslanders were going to get the opportunity to go to university and to achieve their full potential.

It now appears that all of that has been placed in jeopardy. Liberal and National Party members and senators have worked to try to stop this from happening. I can assure you, Mr Speaker, that I will be going out and about throughout my electorate and the state of Queensland telling the young people that the members of the Liberal and National parties in Queensland do not want them to have a place in higher education. Those members have worked in this parliament to stop young people from going to university. This is their commitment to higher education. This is how they demonstrate their commitment to young people. They are trying to starve the universities of funds.

I will not let this issue die. The Queensland opposition members—the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), the member for Fadden (Mr Jull), the member for Ryan (Mr Moore), the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford)—can all go back to their constituencies and explain to the year 12 students why they have starved the universities in Queensland of funds and stopped the young people from going to university.

You explain to the year 12 students who have just sat for their exams and are now waiting for their OP scores to be published and for university placements to be offered why they will not be offered a place at one of the great universities in Queensland. Explain to them that you were so mean-spirited that you would not allow the funds to be allocated in the budget. You will be made to account for your actions in this place and in the other place.

I can assure you, Mr Speaker, that I will make sure that every year 12 student throughout Queensland is made aware of the actions of the members of the Liberal Party and the National Party in moving to prevent funds being allocated so that 4,200 extra young people can be placed in universities, giving them the opportunity to fulfil their potential. Liberal Party and National Party senators should hang their heads in shame. I will be making sure that the Liberal Senate team going into the 1996 election—Senator Herron and Senator Ian Macdonald—are made to account for the way in which they have acted in relation to this legislation.

How can members of the Liberal and National parties dare to look year 12 students in their electorates in the face? I went and visited every year 12 student in my electorate and I committed myself to work to get extra university places. I will continue to do that. Members of the Liberal and National parties have no credibility and no integrity when it comes to caring about young people and families when they are willing to act in such a disgraceful and destructive way. They have cut funds that will provide for extra university places in Queensland. It is an absolute shame. Those opposite should hang their heads in shame.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to participate in the adjournment debate and to indicate to the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) that if he believes that he has a monopoly on caring and integrity perhaps he might care to join me in making representations to the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) to ensure that the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill is passed through the Senate and is no longer listed so far down the Senate legislation list that there is a real risk that it will not be debated. The bill has already been through this House. There is a real risk that the bill will not be processed before Christmas.

PARA.TAB: It will deny a major industry in my electorate the opportunity to effectively retail and make available to Australians the therapeutic goods that it manufactures. The company affected is the Brauer company which has a processing factory in the Barossa Valley. The Brauer family came to the Barossa Valley as part of the German settlement movement in the 1840s. The Brauers were associated with pharmaceutical goods production and processing in the Barossa Valley. In 1972 they went into production of their own homeopathic medicines.

The Brauers have been at the cutting edge of homoeopathic research and the retailing of homoeopathic goods across Australia and, in 1987, were the recipients of the Lady Cilento Award for the production of homoeopathic medicines. They are now in the situation of having several new products that they wish to list, that they have indicated they have been processing and that they wish to market. The products have met all the various standards that are required by Australian legislation. The fact that the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill is still waiting, unprocessed through the Senate, means that they cannot list these new products on the marketplace. As a result, their managing director, Mr Mark Wuttke, tells me that since 1 July this year he has had to place four full-time people out of the work force, two other jobs are currently at risk and they estimate they have lost over $150,000 in sales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speak to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.

—The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development rightly interjects. I have raised this with Senator Crowley and her office and they have indicated that they intend to take a look at this and hope to list it in the Senate for next week, but there is no assurance that this will happen. It is that assurance that I seek. It is for that reason that I am using the adjournment debate to alert both Senator Crowley and her staff to the urgency of this matter.

PARA.TAB: Here is a company that has the capacity to generate further export revenue for Australia, a company that has earned for itself an international reputation as a reliable supplier, a company that has, through its research and development arms, developed new products and is currently unable to market them because the bill has not proceeded. It is not a bill that is causing either the government or the opposition any angst. What is important is that it is listed for debate in the Senate before passage through the Senate. It is important that that occurs before the House rises at the end of next week.

The absurdity of this is that the legislation is not legislation that the opposition has opposed. It is legislation that the government has introduced and the opposition supports it. But it has not received the necessary prior rating in the processing of legislation through the Senate for me or this company to feel confident that it will be passed by the end of next week. If it does not become law, the losses that the company is currently sustaining will continue. That would be absurd when there is nothing that the company is doing that is counter to the law and there is nothing that the opposition has done that has frustrated the government in this exercise. It is urgent that those managing government business in the Senate recognise that this legislation ought to have prior treatment in the interests of not only this company but also all those involved in pharmaceutical goods manufacture and the manufacture of homoeopathic medicines across Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to speak about one of the most successful initiatives ever initiated by any government in Australia. I refer to the national aged care system that operates in this country, whereby licensed beds for nursing homes and hostels are issued by the Department of Human Services and Health and those positions are subsidised. By the issue of this seeding capital and the guarantee that there will be a bed available for a frail aged person, if this is correctly managed it can become a major business, a major employer, in many country towns.

PARA.TAB: A little over a week ago I had the pleasure of attending the annual general meeting of the Dungog Nursing Home. This is a 20-bed hostel and a 20-bed nursing home complex. It was built in 1989. At that time I was serving as a councillor on Dungog Shire Council. It was built with the aid of a $1 million grant from the federal government. Today that nursing home-hostel not only provides top quality accommodation for 40 frail aged people but also provides 38 jobs in a small rural town. It has accumulated property and has assets worth $3 million. The phenomenal success that this organisation has enjoyed has resulted in its acquiring land and building eight self-care units, with another four to be constructed. As a result of being given $1 million five years ago, this organisation now has three tiers of aged care available and employs people at the same time.

In cases such as this I generally do not single out individuals but in this case I am sure the committee will not object to my mentioning their executive: Mr Ray Nielson, chairman; Councillor Anne MacDonald, secretary; and Mr Reg Howard, treasurer. These people have been totally dedicated to seeing their dream come to fruition. It is with great respect that I mention them. In five short years I am sure the whole committee believe that their plan has succeeded beyond their wildest dreams.

This nursing home has become a focal point of the whole community. Head of nursing Amanda Lydon, the deputy director of the hostel Susan Adphaloosy, the clerical person Carol Passenow and Sister Margaret Emry are just some of the people who work behind the scenes to continue the care of the aged. Assisting the full-time staff are people enrolled in the local skillshare projects. I know that there is an opinion held by some members opposite that these training programs often only play at training and do not lead to a real job, but in this case they are definitely providing a major service to members of the community and they will lead to jobs because this is an expanding industry. Some of these staff provide tuition to these students.

The nursing home has also been involved in many other community projects such as Greening Australia in conjunction with the LEAP project involving school children and the long-term unemployed. This pattern of aged care is repeated in many towns. I am sure that representatives here from rural and regional electorates know exactly what I am talking about because it is repeated there and it is very successful. In the electorate of Paterson we have outstanding community support in towns such as Gloucester, Stroud, Bulahdelah, Hawkesnest, Maitland, Tenilba Bay and Nelson Bay. All of these places have nursing homes, hostels or both. Each is subsidised by the federal government, each providing quality accommodation and care and, more importantly, creating jobs.

I can assure the House that every opportunity I get I remind the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) what a great system this is. In an ageing population I believe it is vital that we dedicate more resources to this system of care. The subsidy we give is compensated by the jobs that are created and these are often in towns where traditional industries have disappeared and where the opportunity for job creation is minimal. I would urge all members of this House to support this great system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the adjournment debate tonight to voice my concern for the 4,500 newsagents of Australia who I believe are subject to attack because of, perhaps, an aberration in the application of our new competition policy. I believe that while we must have competition—there is no doubt about that—it has to be leavened with a degree of sanity. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, which is the old Trade Practices Commission—still chaired by professor Allan Fels, by the way—appears to be too focused on the theory of competition rather than the reality. I do not think they can see the wood for the trees. While they obviously want to get a better deal for consumers—and so does everybody in this place—we have to be concerned about the fabric and the structure which provide that service to the consumers. That fabric and structure involves the 4,500 newsagents operating around Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have to be concerned about what might occur, which would be the removal of the delivery monopoly and other benefits enjoyed by newsagents. Instead of bringing about a better system for the sale and delivery of newspapers and magazines, removing, revoking or modifying the current authorisations could leave both newsagencies and public arrangements in disarray. The Trade Practices Commission, I believe, needs to finalise its very longwinded decisions as quickly as possible. It is worth noting that the Fraser government was quoted in the newspapers as saying at that time, which was in 1978-79, that the widespread availability of newspapers and magazines and the low cost home delivery service were the principal public benefit. The point I want to make is that there are public benefits from the current newsagent system. It has certainly worked very successfully in the distribution of newspapers throughout this country.

The coalition has a very clear perspective on where it stands on this issue. The coalition and I support the continuation of the current system of distribution for newspapers and magazines, with one accredited newsagent for a particular territory. The fact is that the newsagents' network in this country, together with the 25,000 subagents, provides an excellent public service.

If people are as concerned as the coalition and I about preserving small business, we should realise that putting the products at newsagents increasingly into the Woolworths and the Coles is not going to help small business; it is going to destroy it. It is certainly going to provide a situation where individual small businesses will be pushed out. I can even envisage a situation where there is a major shopping complex with perhaps even 80 shops and if things go the way they seem to be going—it is drawing a long bow—you could end up with Coles at one end, Woolworths at the other end and absolutely nothing in between. I do not think that is appropriate; it is total madness.

Australia's 4,500 newsagents are located in every significant shopping area right across Australia. They provide face to face service to more than one million customers every day. They represent one of the last bastions of major successful family business enterprise and employ in excess of 20,000 staff. A great many of them are youngsters. If we are concerned about youth unemployment we should remember that businesses like newsagencies do employ young Australians. That, to me, is very important.

The sector turns over more than $3 billion annually and holds the investment hopes of thousands of Australians who have their life savings in their businesses. If they are to be destroyed, I believe there must be compensation. If the authorisation does have to change, there must be compensation for loss of income and the purchase of goodwill to be included in that authorisation. I support the need for compensation and the purchase of the goodwill. If the axe falls on newsagencies, they should not be treated unfairly but I believe the axe should not fall and the system should be left as it is. It works well and it is for the public benefit. It benefits the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I had a meeting with the Independent Retirees in Tasmania—a group that has been at some pains to explain that they have been disadvantaged under government policy. I took the time to go through what this government has done for all pensioners and, specifically, some of the changes for independent retirees that were made after the strategic review into pensioners' income and the assets test.

PARA.TAB: We have agreed to extend deeming to financial investments, which will simplify the way in which income from investments is assessed by the Department of Social Security. We have also abolished the separate fringe benefits income and assets test, enabling all pensioners to receive Commonwealth and state concessions and allowing more people to hold a pension card.

A seniors health card has been introduced offering a range of health related concessions and there has been an easing of the assets test on pensions. There has been a major expansion of financial information services to help older people. There has also been a move to simplify the paperwork involved in applying for a seniors health card and other initiatives.

This government has been very conscious of the problems of independent retirees and we wish to ensure that there is equity between those who are on a government pension and those who are financing their own. In this term we have attempted to rectify some of the injustices—and I think we have succeeded in what has occurred so far.

The one thing that I find is still not sufficiently emphasised in policy development is that people who retire are not necessarily disabled, sick or incapable of contributing to their community. On the contrary, many people retire because they wish to pursue their own interests, develop long held dreams and help their families. Once they have achieved some of their ambitions, they cast around for other tasks that take their fancy. Their skills and expertise are out there, waiting to be tapped.

We need a new approach to the development of policies for older Australians based on the recognition of the important roles played by older people in our community, in family life, in the provision of services and in promoting harmony between generations. I would like to see an integrated strategy that will pull together all the different policy areas, such as income support, housing, community services, home care and tax regimes so that we can meet the changing needs of our older people and recognise their skills.

We need to encourage better health, independence and opportunities for community participation. We need to ensure more flexible working opportunities, security and adequate income for older people. We need to ensure that older people have care and support if and when they need it and in ways which help them remain in familiar surroundings. We need to ensure that government policy meets the diversity of need and circumstances among older people.

An integrated strategy based on these goals would make a great difference to older Australians. I am intending to pursue these goals with the help of older people in my community. I will be urging the government to consider this strategy once we have passed the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lofty Willers has been a policeman for most of his working life. He served in many areas of my electorate. I first met him in Dampier. He attained the rank of inspector and was generally well regarded in the community. He was regarded as a man with a sense of fair play and, as far as policemen go, he was very well accepted.

PARA.TAB: A problem arose in Kalgoorlie over an incident where speed radar traps were set outside a hotel. There were allegations that he was unhappy with the hotel because of the treatment that his daughter had received there. This was deemed to be vindictive. He was charged by the internal investigation branch of the police service. They made it a criminal charge.

The fact is this: even if he did this vindictively—it has been denied that he did—it is not an offence. He was absolutely entitled to do that. So it was not a criminal offence. It appears that the internal investigation branch harassed the hotel into making a complaint. It did not want to make a complaint; it was harassed into making one. It went to a preliminary hearing in court and was thrown out. It was then ex officio indicted by the DPP, and it went to court.

On the first occasion, he was certainly incompetently represented, and the DPP got a conviction. The magistrate sentenced him to two years in gaol, which was certainly very excessive. He appealed that decision, the appeal was upheld and a new trial was ordered. At the new trial, properly represented, it was thrown out in record time. The man was acquitted as he should have been. He should never have been charged.

You then have to look at the affairs of Sergeant Waghorn and Detective Christmass, two officers in the drug squad. They were sent to interview a person who had actually sent Homebake to someone in Carnarvon who had died as a result. This person was interviewed, his premises were searched and he was found to have in his possession the manufacturing equipment. He was clearly in some sort of trouble. This man made a statement and it went to court. In court, the man, Mr O'Halloran, defended himself. It was only natural that he should seek every avenue open to him, and I certainly do not deny him that right. He threw doubt on the validity of the signatures that were on every page of the statement.

It was in evidence that Sergeant Waghorn had said to him on several occasions, `Will you sign this again?' This matter was raised in the court and it was decided by the magistrate that there had to be some study into whether it was his signature or not. The experts simply could not agree so the guy was acquitted.

Then, Christmass and Waghorn were once again ex officio indicted by the DPP. They went to the preliminary hearing and it was thrown out. So, once again, they were ex officio indicted and it went to court. This dragged on for two years. When it went to court, O'Halloran, who by this time had got himself off heroin, decided that the honourable thing to do would be to go forward and say, `It was my signature. In all probability I did sign it.'

The DPP knew this all the time yet it refused to call him as a witness. Had he been called as a witness there would have been no case. The DPP is duty bound to call all the evidence, and it failed to do this. It was prepared to put these two police officers through two years of sheer hell. It cost the families of the officers dearly. In my view, those two officers were doing a great job for the community and were unmercifully harassed.

The common factors in all this harassment are the Director of Public Prosecutions, John McKechnie, and the Deputy Commissioner of Police, Les Ayton. They are the common factors through all these things, and this is just a handful of matters. I have literally many cases here where the same sort of thing has applied. There has to be some real look at what is happening to justice in Western Australia. If there was ever a need for an inquiry, it is for an additional inquiry into the administration of justice in Western Australia. Such an inquiry is long overdue. If we are to return some dignity and some sense of cohesion and purpose to the police force, we must have an inquiry. Many people in the police force want it. By and large, the police are honourable people. (Time expired)

. . . he was not aware of local and State Government concerns about the Fairways Leisure Market going back to 1993 when it was first announced, but he would "happily take it up, because I don't see that as being compatible with airport functions".

PARA.TAB: "If there's concern in councils and the State Government that this is not a sensible use of the airport zone, it ought to be raised with us."

SPEECH.PARA: I find that rather interesting because the first sign of this development was early in 1994 when a site office was put on site to sell these stores. As a result of that site office being there and my picking up literature that showed there were some 650 stalls, I came into this place on 28 February and in a grievance debate said:

. . . I am concerned at some of the commercial developments that are being established at airports such as Moorabbin. I am particularly concerned about the way in which a development—called a leisure park but it really is a large market—is being established at that airport.

PARA.TAB: There will be some 650 stalls at this market site. The total area of the site at the airport will be 27 acres. It will have a car park for some 2,400 cars. Three acres of buildings will accommodate 650 stallholders.

SPEECH.PARA: I went on to say that there were four chambers of commerce in the area which were not supportive of the development. It would involve massive planning requirements which had not been taken into consideration throughout this process, which was a money grab for market stalls on the side. I also said in my speech that the Victorian Minister for Planning, Mr Rob MacLellan, had threatened to cut road services to the Moorabbin airport—that is nothing light, is it?—if the airport proceeded to hold markets on the site. I said:
Mr MacLellan attacked the Federal Airports Corporation in state parliament this month for allowing the airport to build the $3.5 million leisure market . . .

We can go on and on about this process. It just amazes me. In fact, I suspect what we ought to be calling the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) is the fireman for the minister. We have had people going out to the site to put out the fire and saying, `Look, if only we'd known something about this, we would have dealt with it. If somebody in the state or local government area had said something, we would have dealt with it.' I came into this federal parliament and said that the local government authorities were upset, that the chambers of commerce were upset and that the state government minister had raised the issue. TALK.START.PARA: —They have been vindicated.

—That is exactly right, as the member for Goldstein says. The fact of the matter is that we really do need to recognise that this government is out of control. At the next election there will be a lot of people in my area who will remember exactly what has happened in this case. SPEECH.PARA: The Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1995 proposes amendments in the light of a recent court decision that has jeopardised the viability of the voluntary administration scheme under part 5.3A of the Corporations Law, which commenced operation in June 1993.

PARA.TAB: Part 5.3A of the Corporations Law provides a regime for companies to enter voluntary administration as an alternative to liquidation. It is an extremely popular method of dealing with companies in financial difficulty. The scheme allows a company in financial difficulty to enter into a deed of company arrangement with its creditors. This enables the company to continue trading for a period with a view to producing some return for creditors, rather than being wound up immediately.

The advantage of taking this course from a creditor's perspective is that if the company is allowed to continue operating its business, there is a likelihood that a better return to creditors will be obtained than if the company is liquidated immediately. The mechanism also serves to avoid the costs and delays often associated with liquidations.

Statistics published by the Australian Securities Commission and industry bodies show that the voluntary administration scheme is an increasingly popular means of dealing with corporate financial difficulties. In a significant proportion of cases, companies enter into deeds of company arrangements with their creditors, rather than proceeding directly to winding up, in an effort to save the company or at least its business.

In some cases, after a period of trading under a deed of company arrangement, it will become apparent that the continued trading of the company will not be successful. In that case, the creditors are permitted to have the company liquidated immediately. The Corporations Law provides for an automatic transition to a creditor's voluntary winding up in this regard.

In June this year, His Honour Mr Justice Cohen of the New South Wales SupremeCourt held—in Re Crawford House Press Pty Ltd (1995) 13 ACLC 874; (1995) 17 ACSR 295—that where persons deal with a company under a deed of company arrangement and that company moves into liquidation, those persons may not make a claim in the winding up for any outstanding liabilities of the company in relation to those dealings. His Honour remarked that this is not a result that could have been intended by the legislature and therefore called for urgent legislative amendment. In the wake of the Crawford House decision, there have been calls for urgent legislative amendment, particularly from practitioners in the insolvency area.

As this matter is of such importance to ongoing and future voluntary administrations, the Government has moved swiftly to introduce a bill which contains amendments to overcome the apparent anomaly in the Corporations Law.

The bill contains only two substantive amendments to the Corporations Law. The first is designed to ensure that debts and claims arising while a company is under a deed of company arrangement are admissible to proof in a subsequent winding up. The second is intended to protect the validity of acts of liquidators who admitted such debts and claims on the basis that they were provable, prior to commencement of the amendments in the bill.

The bill is not expected to have any significant financial impact on Government or business as the proposed amendments clarify the operation of existing provisions of the Corporations Law and will not result in additional costs. The explanatory memorandum describes the potential impact on creditors.

In conclusion, I confirm that, in accordance with the heads of agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation, the Ministerial Council on Corporations has been consulted and has given approval for the introduction of the bill into the parliament. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Corporations Law Amendment Bill 1995 is designed to overcome a recent decision of Cohen J in the New South Wales Supreme Court in Re Crawford House Pty Ltd. The decision highlights an unintended anomaly with the voluntary administration provisions of the Corporations Law and adversely affects creditors who deal with a company controlled by directors as distinct from an administrator while under voluntary administration.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the background to these administrative provisions, the provisions of the Corporations Law entitled `Administration of a company's affairs with the view to executing a deed of company arrangement', part 5.3A, commenced operation on 23 June 1993. The objects of this part are to provide for an insolvent company to be administered so that the chances of the company continuing in existence are maximised; and, if it is not possible for the company to continue, for a better return to creditors than would result from an immediate winding up.

Before this part, generally speaking, the only remedy available to a company in trouble was to have it wound up. Other options of a scheme of arrangement or official management, requiring 100 per cent return, were cumbersome and costly. There was, therefore, very little prospect of a potentially viable business being able to continue in existence.

The Corporate Law Reform Act 1992 inserted a new part 53.A, a scheme for voluntary administration of a company which is in financial difficulties. Through the agreement with creditors, the company can continue to trade under external supervision of the administrator in the hope that it might ultimately trade out of its difficulties. The means by which this is done is under a deed of company arrangement. This has obvious advantages for the directors, shareholders and creditors of the company. It also means that the company can continue to employ people and contribute to the national economy.

Debts incurred during the operation of the arrangement were thought to be ranked in priority over other unsecured creditors in any winding up. The purpose was to provide an incentive or reward for dealing with a company in difficulties and give it a second chance. Under deeds of company arrangement, it is possible for the creditors to resolve that the administrator not be involved in the carrying out of the business, but the directors of the company be responsible. It was incorrectly assumed by many that the priority in ranking would attract to the debts irrespective of whether the administrator or the directors were carrying out the day-to-day running of the company. However, the Crawford House case held that, due to technical deficiency in the legislation, if debts were incurred by the directors of the company in lieu of the administrator, the debts not only do not rank at all but are not provable.

In the Crawford House case, this bill before the parliament is needed to overcome this decision. On 13 December 1993, Mr Dean Willcocks was appointed administrator of Crawford House Press Pty Ltd. At that time, the company had creditors whose debts totalled $1,344,299. By 23 December 1993, a creditors meeting had resolved that the administrator should cease to be involved in the actual carrying on of the business of the company, but that the administrator should have certain powers should the company default on the arrangement. It was assumed that the company would continue in business and that the company and not the administrator would incur such debts as were necessary for carrying on the business.

The company attempted to trade out of its difficulties, but this was not successful and, in June 1994, creditors decided that the arrangement should be terminated and the company should be wound up. The administrator was appointed liquidator. In that period of time, the company incurred additional debts of $38,118.

The Crawford House decision held that, because the debts were not incurred by the administrator, not only did they not get priority but they were not provable in any subsequent winding up. Mr Justice Cohen said:

SPEECH.PARA: The result of this legislation is that creditors of the administrator received priority in respect of debts incurred by him. Where, as in the present case, and in many similar instances, the deed of company arrangement provides that the administrator is not to be involved in the carrying on of the business but that this will in effect be under the control of the directors, then any trading debts incurred during the period of the term of the deed will be those of the company and not those of the administrator.
He went on to say:

[These debts] were incurred after the commencement of administration and the result is that they appear to have been omitted from any category of debts recoverable in a subsequent winding up because of what appears to be a gap in the legislation. It is not satisfactory that the position should be left as it is and it requires urgent legislative amendment.

In relation to the issue of priority of debt incurred by administrators, under the existing legislation, debts incurred prior to a company entering into a deed of company arrangement can be proved in a winding up. However, if a company subsequently enters into a deed of arrangement, then debts incurred by the administrator during the period after the deed has been entered into take priority in any subsequent litigation.

PARA.TAB: On the issue of priority and provability of directors' debts, if under a deed the directors of a company are responsible for running the day-to-day affairs of the company then the decision of Crawford House means that not only are debts incurred by the directors without priority but they are not even admissible to prove in any subsequent winding-up. This is because section 513B of the Corporations Law provides a number of alternative dates for the commencement of a winding-up.

Where, as in the case of Crawford House, the company was under a deed of company arrangement immediately prior to the resolution to wind up the company being passed, the winding-up is taken to have commenced on the day the deed began. The winding up therefore refers back to this earlier date. This earlier date is defined as the relevant date in the Corporations Law. Debts are provable if incurred before the relevant date. For the purposes of admissibility of debts, the date of the deed of company arrangement and the date of liquidation are no longer different dates. The date of liquidation becomes the date the deed of company arrangement was entered into.

In relation to an exception for administrators, there is, however, a mechanism whereby debts incurred between the commencement of the administration and the winding-up can be proved and have priority. This mechanism is granted to the administrator. After all, the legislation makes the date of liquidation relate back to the date the administration commenced. Any dates incurred after the liquidation cannot be proved. This means debts incurred in an administration would ordinarily, without an exception being provided, neither have priority nor be provable, because they would have been debts incurred after the date of liquidation. Section 556 provides a suitable mechanism by spelling out that a relevant authority has priority during that time, and defining the administration as a relevant authority.

There are some concerns by interest groups. The Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia has indicated that many solicitors have advised their clients to refuse to supply companies that are subject to an arrangement except on a cash on delivery basis. The Law Council and the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia have urged amendment.

The government is proposing to amend section 553 of the Corporations Law, which deals with debts or claims that are provable in a winding-up. Its amendment seeks to ensure that all such debts or claims incurred by the directors of the company will be provable. It is important to recognise that the government's bill will not give priority to debts incurred by the directors of the company under a deed of company arrangement. The government's proposal therefore will not reward those creditors who deal with directors of a company rather than an administrator, under a deed of company arrangement.

What will happen is that, even though the debts are incurred after the relevant date, the time for which such new creditors will be able to prove will be extended to the date of termination of the deed of company arrangement. It is simply seeking to ensure that, where the existing creditors choose to allow the directors to run the company, the debts incurred while under the arrangement are at least provable. They are not seeking to give those debts any priority over other existing unsecured creditors. It treats them as normal unsecured creditors.

This will have the effect of discouraging creditors from dealing with a company under an arrangement if the directors are in charge. If the directors are in charge, all unsecured creditors will rank together; but if the administrator is in charge debts incurred under a deed will rank in priority. This is a clear policy decision to create an incentive for existing creditors to allow a costly administrator to take charge of the daily affairs of the company. It creates a disincentive for the creditors, who are after all the ones who have the most to lose, to choose the less expensive option of allowing the directors to run the day-to-day affairs of the company.

There will also be a retrospective provision. This is in order to validate the actions of any liquidator who has recognised a debt which, if challenged on the basis of the Crawford House decision, should have been rejected by the liquidator. This retrospectivity will date back to the commencement on 23 June 1993 of the voluntary administration scheme introduced by the Corporate Law Reform Act.

The coalition believes that the problem clearly needs to be fixed. However, we believe there may be a better way to deal with it. Since it is the creditors who have the most to lose, it seems appropriate to allow them to make a choice as to whether an administrator or directors should have the day-to-day running of the company under an arrangement. There should not be an incentive to choose an administrator over the directors. In order to give them an unfettered choice, there should be a reward for all creditors dealing with a company in difficulties and giving it a second chance, irrespective of whether the directors or the administrator have the day-to-day running of the company.

The appropriate reward is that the debts will rank in priority over other unsecured creditors. In order to achieve that end, we will move an amendment to ensure that the debts incurred by directors have the same priority ranking as those incurred by an administrator. Our amendments will define directors in such a situation as a relevant authority, like an administrator, for the purposes of these sections. All debts, irrespective of whether the administrator or the directors had the day-to-day running of the company, would then get priority.

The coalition feels this is a better way to resolve the decision in the Crawford House case. Of course, if our amendment is unsuccessful then we will support the bill. However, when we deal with the matter in detail I will move the amendment that has been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is not surprising. In order to speak to the amendment let me go into a little background. The Corporations Law Amendment Bill has been brought on with some urgency, which is understandable because of what was described by Justice Cohen in the New South Wales Supreme Court decision of Re Crawford House Pty Ltd as a loophole. That decision was handed down as recently as 13 June 1995 and His Honour said of the loophole that it is not satisfactory that the position should be left as it is and that it requires urgent legislative amendment.

PARA.TAB: In order to understand what His Honour was concerned about, a little further background may assist. An administrator was appointed to the company, Crawford House Pty Ltd, in December 1993. At a creditors meeting it was resolved that the company should enter into a deed of company arrangement in the form approved by the creditors. A clause of the deed provided that the administrator should cease carrying on the company's business and instead the company itself was to continue in business and pay money to the administrator for the purpose of his making distributions in a prescribed manner.

The company continued to trade, but not very successfully. A meeting of creditors was held in June 1994 at which it was resolved to terminate the deed of company arrangement and wind up the company. During the period from December 1993 to June 1994 when the company was trading under the deed of company arrangement, additional debts of over $38,000 were incurred. The liquidator sought the court's directions as to whether the creditors in question were unsecured creditors, creditors as part of the costs of the winding up or not creditors at all.

The relevant provisions of the Corporations Law were quite new. They were introduced by the Corporate Law Reform Act 1992, which commenced in part in February and in part in June of 1993. The law provides that where—immediately before a voluntary winding-up resolution is passed—a company is under administration, the winding-up is taken to have commenced on the day on which the administration began. In the Crawford House case, the date of commencement of the winding-up was the day when the administration began: namely, a date in December 1993.

A problem arises, because the Corporations Law also provides that the debts which are admissible to prove against a company that is winding up are all debts the circumstances giving rise to which occurred before the day on which the winding-up began. This drew from Justice Cohen the following conclusion:

SPEECH.PARA: The result is that when there has been an administration of the company, whether followed by a deed of company arrangement or not, provable debts are those where the circumstances giving rise to them occurred before the date of commencement of the administration.

Since the company traded during the period of administration under the control of the directors, any trading debts incurred during the period of the term of the deed will be those of the company and not of the administrator.

PARA.TAB: Justice Cohen concluded, in regard to those debts:

SPEECH.PARA: They were incurred after the commencement of administration and the result is that they appear to have been omitted from any category of debts recoverable in a subsequent winding up because of what appears to be a gap in the legislation.

This results in the regrettable situation that there appears to be no right in those who became creditors of the company or whose debts were increased during the period of the operation of the deed, to prove for those debts or increased debts.

The law provides that the voluntary administration provisions of the Corporations Law serve two purposes. The first is to maximise the chances of the company's continuing in existence. The second, which is really an alternative, is, if it is not possible for the company to continue, to get a better return for the company's creditors and members than would result from an immediate winding-up.

PARA.TAB: Before the Crawford House decision, it was thought that debts incurred during the operation of a deed of company arrangement ranked in priority to other unsecured creditors in any winding-up. The reason for this is that such creditors should have an incentive or reward for dealing with the company in difficulties and, in so doing, giving it a second chance. The Crawford House case has made it clear that these creditors do not have any such priority. However, the result is otherwise where the administrator, rather than the directors, is carrying out the day-to-day running of the company. (Extension of time granted) Trading debts incurred by an administrator will then rank in priority to other unsecured debts.

The purpose of this bill is to ensure that, where the creditors choose to allow the directors to run the company, debts incurred while the deed of company arrangement is in force will be provable in the subsequent winding-up. But the bill does not give those debts any priority over other unsecured debts. The bill proposes to treat those creditors as normal unsecured creditors.

As my colleague the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) has said, the effect of this is to discourage creditors from dealing with the company under a deed of company arrangement if the directors, rather than an administrator, are in charge. If an administrator is in charge under the deed of company arrangement, the debts incurred during the period of the deed of company arrangement will rank in priority to other unsecured creditors. The effect of this, as the member for Berowra has explained, will clearly provide a disincentive for those creditors considering extending further credit to the company to help it continue to trade.

If the creditors want to ensure that the increase in their debts will be protected by a priority ranking, they will need to appoint an administrator to run the company, rather than allow the directors to control the day-to-day management of the company. The disadvantage of this is that the less expensive option is likely to be having the directors run the company. In order that the creditors have a real choice as to whether they appoint an administrator to run the business or allow the company directors to continue running the business, all trade debts incurred under a deed of company arrangement should have the same priority ranking.

To this end I support the amendment moved by the member for Berowra. The amendment will have the effect of including the directors, along with the administrator, within the definition of `a relevant authority' for the purpose of voluntary administration provisions.

It is important that this anomaly in the legislation is rectified, and the bill will do that. There is, I should mention also, retrospective application of the bill. This is in order to validate the actions of a liquidator who has recognised a debt which, according to the Crawford House case, should have been rejected by the liquidator. The retrospectivity will date back to the commencement in June 1993 of the voluntary administration scheme provisions of the Corporations Law. This retrospectivity would be objectionable if someone had arranged their affairs in reliance on the debts not being provable. Such a person or company would be seeking to take advantage of the loophole in the legislation to avoid paying a properly incurred debt. Such a person or company cannot expect the protection of this parliament for that purpose.

Retrospective legislation as a class is invidious, and there are few exceptions. Since the retrospective element of this bill is designed to ensure that a particular group of creditors will have the right to prove for their debts in the winding up of the debtor company, it is difficult to see the disadvantage of that provision. Obviously, the preferable course would be for the government to have got its legislation right the first time round.

The coalition, as the member for Berowra has pointed out, does not oppose this bill, but is of the view that all debts incurred by a company under a deed of company arrangement should have a priority ranking over the unsecured debts. To that end, I support the amendment moved by the member for Berowra.
